As the national broadcaster, it operates under direct state control and funding, serving as the government's primary broadcasting outlet.

organization: Oman Establishment for Press, Publication and Advertising (OEPPA)
description: OEPPA is one of Oman's largest and most influential state media organizations, established by Royal Decree. It publishes the country's two official dailies including the English-language Oman Daily Observer and Oman Daily Arabic. As a government-controlled media house, it serves as the primary newspaper publisher in Oman, operating under direct state oversight. The organization also handles publishing and advertising services, reflecting the government's media interests and editorial direction.

Established by royal decree in 1997, Oman News Agency (ONA) is the official state news agency of Oman, operating under the Ministry of Information. As a government-controlled media outlet, it serves as the primary source of official news and information in both Arabic and English. The agency recently modernized its digital presence with a new website and mobile application to enhance content delivery. Led by Director General Dr. Mohammed Mubarak Al-Araimi, ONA provides comprehensive coverage of government activities, national developments, and state-sanctioned news.

Established in 1993-1994, the Palestinian Broadcasting Corporation (PBC) is the state broadcaster of Palestine, controlled by the Palestinian Authority leadership in Ramallah. It operates multiple platforms including Voice of Palestine radio and two TV channels (Palestine TV and Palestine Live) broadcasting across the Middle East, North America, and Europe via various satellite networks. The organization serves as the official voice of the Palestinian people, focusing on Palestinian affairs, news, and political content aligned with the Palestinian Authority's positions.

Al-Aqsa Media Network is Hamas's primary media organization operating in Gaza Strip, comprising Al-Aqsa TV, Al-Aqsa Voice Radio, and Shehab News Agency. The network serves as a propaganda platform for Hamas, broadcasting news, talk shows, and content promoting the organization's narrative. Known for inciting anti-Israeli sentiment and spreading Hamas's ideology, it plays a crucial role in the group's communication strategy. The network has been criticized internationally for promoting extremist content and terrorist activities.

Al-Hayat al-Jadida is the official daily newspaper of the Palestinian National Authority (PNA), launched in Gaza City in 1994. As a state-controlled media outlet, it consistently reflects the PNA's political positions and narratives. The paper has faced criticism for publishing controversial content, including antisemitic rhetoric and propaganda. It operates alongside other official PA media institutions like the Palestine Broadcasting Corporation and WAFA news agency, serving as a key communication channel for Palestinian leadership.

WAFA, established in 1972 by the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO), is the official Palestinian state news agency. Initially created to counter Israeli narratives, it now operates under the Palestinian National Authority's control. The agency provides news coverage heavily focused on Palestinian perspectives, particularly regarding Israeli-Palestinian conflicts, settlements, and human rights issues. While serving as a vital Palestinian media voice, its reporting reflects official Palestinian government positions and maintains strong pro-Palestinian editorial stance.
owner: Palestinian National Authority (through PLO Executive Committee)

organization: Al Wasat Media and Publishing Company
description: Felesteen is a daily newspaper published in Gaza City since 2007 by Al Wasat Media and Publishing Company. The media outlet is closely associated with Hamas, being founded by local entrepreneurs with connections to the organization. While technically a private media company, its editorial line strongly aligns with Hamas's positions, making it effectively a propaganda outlet for the group in the Palestinian territories.
owner: Group of local entrepreneurs connected to Hamas

description: Al Jazeera Media Network is a state-funded media organization headquartered in Doha, Qatar, that presents itself as an independent news outlet while receiving substantial funding from the Qatari government. The network operates multiple channels including Al Jazeera Arabic and Al Jazeera English, broadcasting worldwide with a significant focus on the Arab world. While known for its extensive international coverage and investigative journalism, the network has faced criticism for potential bias in regional reporting and its relationship with Qatar's government interests. Recently transitioning towards digital-first strategy in some markets, it maintains influential presence in global news media through TV, digital platforms, and social media.

Qatar Media Corporation (formerly Qatar General Broadcasting and Television Corporation) is Qatar's state-owned public broadcasting network established in 1977. The organization is fully controlled by the Qatari government, which appoints all top management positions. QMC operates various television, radio, and digital media platforms, providing news and entertainment content while serving as a key instrument of state media influence. The current CEO is Sheikh Abdulaziz bin Thani Al Thani.

organization: Dar Al-Watan Printing, Publishing and Distribution WLL
description: Dar Al-Watan is a prominent private media company in Qatar operating in printing, publishing, and distribution services. The company is known for publishing the Qatar Tribune, an English-language newspaper in Doha. Led by CEO Abdulrahman Al Qahtani and Executive Director Ihsan Ghazal, it operates with significant influence in Qatar's media landscape. While privately owned, the company maintains close ties with state interests, reflecting Qatar's controlled media environment.

Gulf Publishing and Printing Company (GPPC), established in 1978, is a major Qatari media company owned by members of the ruling family. It publishes Gulf Times, Qatar's leading English-language newspaper, and other publications. While technically private, it maintains strong ties to the state and ruling family, with content generally aligned with government positions. The company has modernized operations with ISO certifications and advanced ERP systems.
owner: Sheikh Hamad Bin Khalifa and other Qatari citizens

description: Established in 1986 by Qatari businessmen, Dar Al Sharq is Qatar's largest media institution, providing printing, publishing, and distribution services. The group publishes Al Sharq, Qatar's largest daily newspaper, and The Peninsula. While privately owned, it maintains close ties with the government, regularly documenting state achievements and organizing state-aligned events. Known for its pro-government stance in coverage of local and international news.

Qatar News Agency (QNA), established in 1975 by Amiri Decree, is Qatar's state-owned news agency and the second oldest Gulf news agency. As the official news service of Qatar, it provides comprehensive coverage of local, international, sports, and economic news. QNA plays a significant role in Qatar's state media apparatus and was notably involved in a 2017 hacking incident that contributed to the Gulf diplomatic crisis. The agency operates under direct government control and serves as a key instrument for Qatar's state communications.

The Saudi Broadcasting Authority (SBA) is Saudi Arabia's state-run broadcasting entity under the Ministry of Media. Operating from its headquarters in Riyadh with approximately 4,000 staff, it controls a vast network of 23 AM radio stations, 160 TV stations, and 100 FM radio stations. The organization serves as the government's primary media arm, managing key channels like Al Saudiya and Al Ekhbariya. As a state-controlled outlet, it strictly adheres to government messaging and editorial policies, functioning as the Kingdom's official broadcasting voice.
owner: Ministry of Media, Government of Saudi Arabia

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: MBC Group is the largest media company in the Middle East and North Africa, operating over 13 free-to-air TV channels and 3 radio stations. Founded in 1991 in London, it later moved to Dubai (2002) and Riyadh. As a Saudi state-influenced media conglomerate, it provides entertainment, news, and streaming services through its Shahid platform. While maintaining high production values, the network's editorial content aligns with Saudi government perspectives, particularly after the 2018 majority acquisition by the Saudi sovereign wealth fund.
owner: Public Investment Fund (54%), Waleed bin Ibrahim Al Ibrahim (36%), Other investors (10%)

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: Saudi Research and Media Group (SRMG) is a state-backed media conglomerate and the leading integrated media group in the MENA region. Operating in an environment without independent media, it publishes numerous publications including Arab News. While publicly traded, it maintains strong state connections and operates under Saudi government influence. The group has diversified into digital media, journalism training through SRMG Academy, and cultural initiatives. As of 2024, it remains financially robust with total assets of over 5.7 billion SAR.
owner: Al Ahli Capital Fund 13 (29.90%), Al Ahli Capital Fund 4 (29.90%), Other Shareholders (40.20%)

description: The Saudi Press Agency (SPA), established in 1971, is Saudi Arabia's official state news agency operating under the Ministry of Media. As the kingdom's primary news source, it gathers and distributes local and international news in multiple languages. While it claims to follow professional best practices and modern communication techniques, as a state-controlled outlet it serves as the government's official voice, making it an important tool for Saudi state messaging and propaganda.
owner: Ministry of Media of Saudi Arabia

organization: General Organization of Radio and TV - Syria (ORTAS)
description: ORTAS is Syria's state broadcaster founded in 1960 and based in Damascus. Operating under the Ministry of Information's control, it serves as the country's primary television and radio outlet, broadcasting in Arabic, English, and French. As the regime's main propaganda arm, it functions as the official source of Syrian news, particularly during times of political and economic pressure. The organization maintains strict editorial alignment with government positions.

organization: Syrian Arab Publishing and Distributing Company
description: Syrian Arab Publishing and Distributing Company is a media conglomerate that operates several outlets including Al Watan newspaper and Sama TV. The company is owned by Rami Makhlouf, cousin of Syria's president Bashar al-Assad, making it effectively a regime-controlled media entity despite its private ownership structure. The company's outlets are known to promote pro-government narratives and are subject to international sanctions.

organization: Al-Wahda Foundation for Press, Printing, Publishing and Distribution
description: Al-Wahda Foundation is Syria's largest state-owned print media publisher, operating under direct control of the Ministry of Information. It manages all state-owned print outlets in Syria, including major newspapers Al-Thawra and Tishreen. The foundation serves as a key propaganda arm of the Syrian government, with its content strictly aligned with state narratives and policies. In 2022, it expanded its digital presence with six new websites.

The Syrian Arab News Agency (SANA) is Syria's official state news agency, established in 1965 and directly controlled by the Ministry of Information. As a primary propaganda outlet for the Assad regime, SANA consistently promotes government positions, particularly regarding military conflicts and international relations. Their coverage notably demonstrates strong anti-Israel bias and promotes Syrian-Russian military cooperation. The agency provides heavily censored and biased reporting that aligns with state interests, lacking editorial independence and objective journalism standards.

Dubai Media Incorporated (DMI) is the largest media organization in the UAE and official media arm of the Dubai government, established in 2003. Previously operated by Dubai's media department, it's now a state-owned company providing TV, radio, print, and digital media services. The organization is directly controlled by Dubai's leadership, with Deputy Ruler Maktoum bin Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum serving as chairman. DMI functions as a key government communications platform, making it a significant state media outlet in the region.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: Abu Dhabi Media Network is the UAE's leading public service broadcaster and media company, wholly owned by the Abu Dhabi government since 2007. It operates as a multi-platform organization delivering content across digital and traditional platforms in Arabic, English, and Hindi. The network manages 24 market-leading channels and platforms, focusing on news, sports, Emirati affairs, entertainment, education, and children's content. As a state-owned entity, it aligns with government communication objectives while maintaining significant regional influence in the MENA region.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: Sharjah Broadcasting Authority (SBA), formerly Sharjah Media Corporation (SMC), is a government organization established in 2009 through Emiri Decree No. 25. It is dedicated to developing the media industry in the Emirate of Sharjah. The authority operates multiple TV and radio channels, including Pulse 95 Radio, and runs the 'Maraya' video-on-demand platform. As a state-owned broadcaster, it serves as the official media voice of Sharjah emirate.

Sky News Arabia is a 24-hour Arabic news channel headquartered in Abu Dhabi, launched in 2012 as a joint venture between Sky Group and UAE-based International Media Investments. While it maintains editorial standards similar to Sky News UK, its connection to UAE royal family-controlled IMI raises questions about independence on regional issues. The channel provides comprehensive coverage of Middle Eastern and international news, business, sports, and technology, broadcasting to over 50 million households across MENA region.
owner: Sky Group (Comcast) (50%), International Media Investments (IMI - controlled by UAE Deputy PM Sheikh Mansour bin Zayed Al Nahyan) (50%)

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: International Media Investments is a global media company headquartered in Abu Dhabi, established in Abu Dhabi Media Zone Authority. While officially a private investment company focused on building a portfolio of media assets worldwide, it is effectively state-linked through ownership. The company operates bureaux in London, Washington DC, Beirut, and Cairo, with a network of global correspondents. IMI recently formed RedBird IMI, a joint venture with RedBird Capital Partners and Jeff Zucker for media investments.
owner: Abu Dhabi Media Investment Corporation (ADMIC), owned by Sheikh Mansour bin Zayed Al Nahyan

description: Emirates News Agency (WAM), established in November 1976, is the official state news agency of the United Arab Emirates. Beginning operations in June 1977, it functions as the primary news and information dissemination platform for the UAE government. WAM publishes content in multiple languages and serves as the government's main channel for communicating official positions, policy announcements, and national developments. As a state-controlled media outlet, it closely aligns with government perspectives and priorities.
owner: Government of the United Arab Emirates

description: Yemen TV is the official national television station affiliated with Yemen's internationally recognized legitimate government. Operating from both Sanaa and Aden, it primarily focuses on delivering news, reports, and programs that reflect government policies and orientation. The channel serves as a state media platform to convey the Yemeni government's perspective both domestically and to expatriates abroad, while also covering local developments, tourism, and cultural events. Due to Yemen's ongoing conflict, the channel maintains strong alignment with government positions.

Yemen TV is the official national television station affiliated with Yemen's internationally recognized legitimate government. Operating from both Sanaa and Aden, it primarily focuses on delivering news, reports, and programs that reflect government policies and orientation. The channel serves as a state media platform to convey the Yemeni government's perspective both domestically and to expatriates abroad, while also covering local developments, tourism, and cultural events. Due to Yemen's ongoing conflict, the channel maintains strong alignment with government positions.

organization: Yemen General Corporation for Radio and TV
description: Yemen General Corporation for Radio and TV is the state broadcaster of Yemen, operating the country's national radio and television services. The organization is fully funded, governed, and editorially controlled by the Houthi Supreme Political Council. As part of Yemen's tightly controlled media system since 1962, it serves as the government's primary broadcasting outlet, operating under direct oversight of the Ministry of Information.
owner: Government of Yemen (Houthi Supreme Political Council)

description: Al-Thawra ('The Revolution' in Arabic) is Yemen's state-controlled newspaper founded in 1962. Originally aligned with the government, it is now effectively controlled by the Houthi movement following the Yemeni Civil War that began in 2014. The outlet serves as a propaganda platform, particularly evident in its coverage of regional conflicts and politics. The newspaper publishes in Arabic and maintains an online presence where it frequently promotes pro-Houthi and anti-Western narratives.
owner: Controlled by Houthi Movement (De facto), Government of Yemen (De jure)

organization: Al Gomhuryah Establishment for Journalism and Publishing
description: Founded in 1962, Al-Jumhuryah is a leading state-controlled newspaper based in Taiz, Yemen. Originally established by the Yemen Arab Republic government through the Saba General Organization for Press, it ceased operations for four years during the Yemen Civil War (2015-2018). After its 2018 relaunch, it continues to serve as a government mouthpiece, reflecting the complex political dynamics of Yemen's ongoing civil conflict between the Hadi government and Houthi forces.

The Saba News Agency (SABA) is Yemen's official state news agency, established after the unification of Yemen in 1990. As the government's primary media outlet, it operates under strict state control and serves as a key propaganda instrument. The agency maintains close ties with other state media organizations, including China's Xinhua, and primarily focuses on promoting government positions and policies. Its coverage, particularly of regional conflicts and internal affairs, closely aligns with official state narratives.

The Saba News Agency (SABA) is Yemen's official state news agency, established after the unification of Yemen in 1990. As the government's primary media outlet, it operates under strict state control and serves as a key propaganda instrument. The agency maintains close ties with other state media organizations, including China's Xinhua, and primarily focuses on promoting government positions and policies. Its coverage, particularly of regional conflicts and internal affairs, closely aligns with official state narratives.

EPTV is Algeria's oldest and primary state-owned broadcasting service, operating a comprehensive television network that includes nine national channels (TV1-TV9). As the dominant media outlet in Algeria, it maintains complete control over public television broadcasting, including exclusive rights to major sporting events like the Algerian Ligue Professionnelle 1. The network operates under direct state control and serves as the government's main broadcasting platform, offering programming in both Arabic and French languages.

Radio AlgÃ©rie (RA) or EPRS is Algeria's state-owned public radio broadcasting company, established as a public industrial and commercial establishment by decree in 1991. It operates three national stations, one international station, three thematic channels, and 32 regional stations. As the national public broadcaster, it is fully controlled and funded by the Algerian government, serving as the primary state radio outlet.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: El Moudjahid ('The Martyr') is Algeria's state-owned French-language newspaper, established during the Algerian War of Independence as the voice of the FLN resistance. Today, it operates as a government mouthpiece, providing coverage of national and international news with a strong pro-government stance. The publication maintains offices in Algiers and publishes in both French and English, focusing on politics, economy, society, and culture while consistently aligning with official state positions and policies.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: Ech-Chaab is an Arabic-language daily newspaper established on December 11, 1962, shortly after Algeria's independence. As a state-owned publication, it serves as one of Algeria's main public newspapers. The paper operates under government oversight and is known for generally aligning with official state positions. Being a public newspaper, it receives state funding and is considered part of Algeria's state media apparatus.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: El Djoumhouria ('The Republic' in Arabic) is a state-owned daily newspaper published six times a week (Saturday through Thursday) in Oran, Algeria. As one of Algeria's prominent Arabic-language publications, it serves as a national news outlet covering domestic and international affairs. Being state-owned and managed, the newspaper generally aligns with government positions and policies, which may influence its editorial stance and coverage.

Horizons is a professional employer organization (PEO) and business services company based in Algeria that specializes in HR outsourcing, payroll management, recruitment, and global mobility solutions. The company helps international businesses expand into Algeria by providing employer of record (EOR) services, allowing companies to hire and manage staff without establishing a local entity. They also offer comprehensive payroll outsourcing support and event organization services.

AlgÃ©rie Presse Service (APS) is Algeria's official state news agency, operating under direct government control. With regional offices across the country, it provides comprehensive coverage of national and international news in Arabic, French, and English. While it serves as the primary source of official information in Algeria, it has been noted to function as a government propaganda outlet, particularly evident in its coverage of sensitive political issues and international relations. The agency is fully funded by the Algerian government and maintains strict editorial alignment with state positions.

The National Media Authority (NMA) is Egypt's state broadcasting organization, established in 2014 to replace the Ministry of Information. As the country's primary media regulator, it manages and controls state-owned media outlets, including broadcast and print networks. The NMA has extensive powers to appoint and dismiss media heads, direct content, and manage public media institutions. It operates the largest archive of drama, TV, and radio productions in the Middle East. The organization is directly controlled by the government and has been criticized for limiting media independence.
owner: Government of Egypt through Supreme Council for Media Regulation (SCMR)

description: The National Press Authority (NPA) is Egypt's state body that manages and controls all state-owned print and online media outlets. Created in 2014 after the Ministry of Information's abolition, it operates under direct presidential oversight, with its leadership appointed by President El-Sisi. The NPA has broad powers to interfere, manage, and direct Egyptian media outlets, effectively serving as a government control mechanism over press institutions.

Egyptian Media Group (EMG) is Egypt's largest media conglomerate, controlled by the country's General Intelligence Service. It owns major TV networks (CBC, ON TV), newspapers (Youm7), and production companies. The group has strong ties to the Egyptian government and military intelligence, serving as a key propaganda outlet. Through strategic acquisitions since 2016, including Future Group Holding (51%), EMG has consolidated significant control over Egypt's media landscape.
owner: Egyptian General Intelligence Service, Tamer Morsi (Chairman)

description: The Libyan News Agency (LANA) is Libya's official state news agency, operating under direct government control. It primarily covers government activities, diplomatic relations, and local news from a pro-government perspective. The agency serves as the primary communication channel for the Government of National Unity and state institutions, focusing on official announcements and political developments. Previously known as JANA during Gaddafi's era, it was rebranded after the 2011 revolution.

Established in 1959, Maghreb Arabe Presse (MAP) is Morocco's official state news agency, operating under direct government control through the Ministry of Youth, Culture and Communication. The agency provides comprehensive national and international news coverage in multiple languages, including Arabic, French, and Amazigh. While it strives for objective reporting and has adopted a professional ethics charter, its role as a state institution means it generally aligns with official government positions. MAP has garnered regional recognition and maintains partnerships with international news agencies.
owner: Kingdom of Morocco (through the Ministry of Youth, Culture and Communication)

description: Maroc Soir Group is one of Morocco's oldest and most influential publishing companies, based in Casablanca. Founded in 1972 through nationalization of MAS press group, it publishes several prominent newspapers including Le Matin and Assahra Al Maghribiya. Known for its strong pro-government stance and conservative editorial line, the group has significant influence in Moroccan media. With a capital of around $13 million, it operates as a public company while maintaining close ties to government interests.

La Nouvelle Tribune is a prominent weekly francophone Moroccan newspaper focusing on politics, economics, society, sports, and culture. While privately owned by Fahd Yata, it maintains close ties to the Moroccan establishment and generally aligns with government positions. The newspaper provides comprehensive coverage of both national and international news, with particular emphasis on Moroccan affairs and economic developments. It publishes in French and operates a dynamic online news portal.

Ãtablissement de la tÃ©lÃ©vision tunisienne (Al-Wataniyya) is Tunisia's state-run television broadcaster. While it was briefly redesigned to function as a public broadcaster similar to the BBC after the Arab Spring, it has since reverted to strong state control. Under current conditions, the network largely follows government directives and faces significant restrictions on editorial independence, reflecting Tunisia's broader media crackdown and declining press freedoms.

Ãtablissement de la radio tunisienne is Tunisia's state-owned public radio broadcaster, created in 2007 by former president Ben Ali. It operates multiple national radio stations including Radio Tunis, Radio Tunisie Culture, Radio Jeunes, and RTCI. The institution is under direct state control, with its leadership appointed by the government. Current CEO is Henda Ben Alaya Ghribi since 2023. Recent presidential visits and oversight demonstrate continued strong government influence over editorial content.

organization: SociÃ©tÃ© nouvelle d'impression, de presse et d'Ã©dition (SNIPE)
description: SNIPE is a state-owned Tunisian media company with a capital of 5,525,760 TND that publishes 'La Presse' and 'Assahafa' newspapers. Operating under direct government oversight through the Presidency of the Government, which appoints its CEO, it represents one of Tunisia's major state media outlets alongside Radio Tunisienne, TÃ©lÃ©vision Tunisienne, and Tunis Afrique Presse. The company is currently undergoing restructuring, including a planned merger with Dar Assabah.

Tunis Afrique Presse (TAP) is Tunisia's national press agency, established on January 1st, 1961. As the country's primary official news source, it provides comprehensive coverage of political, economic, social, cultural, and sports activities. While it claims to operate with objectivity and neutrality, it functions as a state-controlled media outlet under the Tunisian government, delivering news in multiple languages including Arabic, French, and English. The agency has recently expanded its capabilities with new television studio facilities in 2024.

Founded in 1941, CBC is Canada's national public broadcaster, operating as a Crown corporation. It provides comprehensive news, entertainment, sports, and cultural programming in both English and French across television, radio, and digital platforms. While primarily funded by the government, CBC maintains editorial independence and serves all regions of Canada with a mandate to promote Canadian content and perspectives. The broadcaster offers free access to most content and operates specialized channels including CBC News Network and CBC Gem streaming service.

USAGM is a U.S. government agency overseeing state-funded international broadcasting networks including Voice of America, Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, and others. While legally structured to be editorially independent, it receives approximately $800 million annual federal funding. Its mission is to promote democratic values and American interests abroad, leading some critics to view it as a soft power tool. The agency reaches 394 million people weekly across 100+ countries and 70 languages.

PBS is America's premier public broadcaster and non-commercial television network headquartered in Arlington, Virginia. As a membership organization partnering with over 150 member stations, PBS provides high-quality educational, cultural, and news programming free of charge. Known for shows like Frontline, Masterpiece, and PBS Kids content, it operates independently with funding from member stations, viewer donations, and government grants. PBS maintains strict editorial independence and is widely trusted for its unbiased, educational approach to content delivery across multiple platforms.
owner: Corporation for Public Broadcasting (oversight), PBS Member Stations (cooperative ownership)

description: NPR is an independent, nonprofit media organization founded in 1971 that connects with millions of Americans through its network of over 1,000 public radio stations. Headquartered in Washington D.C. with NPR West in Culver City, it produces highly respected news programs like 'Morning Edition' and 'All Things Considered'. NPR is primarily funded through member station fees, corporate sponsorships, and private donations, maintaining editorial independence while fulfilling its mission to create a more informed public through quality journalism, cultural programming, and music discovery.
owner: Non-profit organization (owned by its member stations)

description: The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) is Australia's national public broadcaster, funded by the Commonwealth Government but operating with editorial independence. Headquartered in Ultimo, NSW, it employs over 3,800 people and delivers comprehensive television, radio, and digital services. The ABC is committed to informing, educating, and entertaining Australians through diverse programming and high-quality journalism. Led by Chair Kim Williams and governed by the ABC Board, it maintains strict editorial standards and corporate responsibility, focusing on Australian content and stories that reflect national identity and interests.

The Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) is Australia's most diverse multicultural and multilingual national broadcaster, established in 1975. Operating as an independent statutory authority, SBS provides comprehensive media services including five TV channels, the world's most linguistically diverse radio network, and digital platforms including SBS On Demand. While primarily government-funded, SBS maintains editorial independence and focuses on promoting cultural diversity, inclusivity, and social cohesion through distinctive Australian storytelling and in-depth international coverage.

Television New Zealand (TVNZ) is New Zealand's primary public broadcaster, operating multiple free-to-air channels and a streaming platform TVNZ+. Created in 1980 through the merger of Television One and South Pacific Television, it broadcasts throughout New Zealand and parts of the Pacific region. While government-owned, TVNZ maintains editorial independence and is primarily funded through commercial advertising rather than public funds, making it unique among public broadcasters. The network provides a mix of news, entertainment, and local content.
owner: New Zealand Government (Minister of Finance (50%), Minister for Media and Communications (50%))

description: Whakaata MÄori ('to mirror/reflect' in MÄori) is New Zealand's national indigenous media organization launched in 2004. As a state-funded broadcaster, it serves as a powerful vehicle for MÄori language and cultural revitalization, offering bilingual programming in both MÄori and English. The network has become a champion of locally produced content and indigenous storytelling, notably leading ANZAC Day commemorations. Through its streaming platform MÄORI+, it provides news, current affairs, sports, drama, and cultural content, making indigenous stories accessible to all New Zealanders.
owner: New Zealand Government, Te Putahi Paoho (MÄori Television Service Electoral College)

description: RNZ is New Zealand's independent public service multimedia organization, established under the Radio New Zealand Act 1995. As a Crown entity, it serves as the nation's primary public broadcaster, providing comprehensive news, current affairs, and cultural content across multiple platforms. It operates RNZ National, RNZ Concert, and RNZ Pacific, with a specific mandate as the designated Lifeline Utility broadcaster during civil emergencies. Known for its editorial independence despite government funding, RNZ produces quality journalism, MÄori programming, and diverse content including documentaries and podcasts.

typology: Independent State Funded and State Managed/Owned Media
description: Pacific Media Network (PMN) is a comprehensive digital media and entertainment platform serving New Zealand's Pacific communities. Owned and operated by the National Pacific Radio Trust and funded by New Zealand on Air, it functions as the country's premier pan-Pasifika broadcasting network. PMN delivers diverse content including news, sports, music, and cultural programming, specifically tailored to both first-generation Pacific migrants and New Zealand-born Pacific peoples. The network emphasizes community engagement and Pacific storytelling through multiple channels, including radio networks and digital platforms, demonstrating its commitment to empowering Pacific voices while maintaining editorial independence despite government funding.

The Fiji Broadcasting Corporation (FBC) is Fiji's national public broadcaster, operating 6 radio stations in iTaukei, Hindi, and English languages, plus FBC TV. While government-funded through airtime purchases and operational support, particularly for public service broadcasts on Radio Fiji One and Two, FBC maintains some editorial independence. Led by CEO Tarun Patel, FBC provides comprehensive news coverage across multiple platforms, focusing on local news, sports, weather, and cultural content. The organization plays a crucial role in Fiji's media landscape as the primary public service broadcaster.

typology: Independent State Funded and State Managed/Owned Media
description: Solomon Islands Broadcasting Corporation (SIBC) is the national radio and television broadcaster of the Solomon Islands, established in 1976 as an independent public service broadcaster. Operating under government oversight, SIBC provides comprehensive national radio coverage with news, educational, and entertainment services. The organization maintains editorial independence while serving as the primary public media outlet in the Solomon Islands, delivering daily news and maintaining online streaming services. The broadcaster plays a crucial role in keeping citizens informed about national and international affairs.

The Broadcasting Services Division, operating under Samoa's Ministry of Communications & Information Technology, is the national public broadcaster of Samoa. It operates Radio 2AP, the country's first public broadcasting station established in 1947. The division provides 24-hour broadcasting services focused on government policy awareness and disaster communications. Under the Broadcasting Act 2010, it operates within a state-controlled framework managing radio spectrum and broadcasting services.

RTNB is Burundi's state-owned public broadcaster under the direct control of the Ministry of Communication. Launched in 1984, it remains the country's only national television network and dominant media outlet. Broadcasting in French and local languages from Bujumbura, it provides 24/7 news coverage and programming. As a state-controlled media organization, it serves as the government's primary communication channel and has been criticized for limited editorial independence.
owner: Government of Burundi - Ministry of Communication

description: The Burundi Press Agency (ABP) is Burundi's state-controlled news agency established as a personalized administration by decree in 1990. It serves as the government's primary news outlet, covering national politics, justice, and regional news. The agency's mission includes gathering comprehensive information within Burundi and maintaining contracts with global press agencies. Operating under direct government oversight, it primarily functions as a state communications channel.

Publications de Presse Burundaise (PPB) is a government-run publications unit in Burundi that controls and operates two main newspapers: Le Renouveau and Ubumwe. As a state-controlled media organization, it is directly overseen by the Burundian government and serves as the primary state publishing apparatus. PPB is responsible for printing and disseminating official information, maintaining a public documentation center, and providing what the government considers 'reliable information' to both citizens and foreigners.

Radiodiffusion TÃ©lÃ©vision de Djibouti (RTD) is Djibouti's state-owned public broadcaster, providing 24/7 radio and television services. As the country's primary media outlet, RTD broadcasts in multiple languages including Arabic, French, Afar, and Somali. The network produces various programs including news, cultural shows, and entertainment content like 'Djib Talent'. Being state-controlled, RTD serves as the government's main communication channel and operates under direct state oversight, potentially affecting its editorial independence.

La Nation is the state-controlled newspaper of Djibouti, publishing in French as the country's primary news outlet. The publication covers national and international news, with a focus on government activities, diplomatic relations, and development projects. As the official state media outlet, it closely follows the government's perspective and serves as a key communication channel for state policies and initiatives. The content typically highlights positive developments and government achievements in Djibouti.

Al-Qarn is a state-controlled Arabic language newspaper in Djibouti, where the media landscape is entirely dominated by the government. It is one of the two highest-circulation newspapers in the country alongside La Nation. The newspaper's management and editing staff are directly appointed by the government, making it a key propaganda outlet in Djibouti's restricted media environment.

The Agence Djiboutienne d'Information (ADI) is Djibouti's state news agency, established on March 1, 1978. It was revitalized in 1999 following a change in government leadership. As the official state media outlet, ADI provides 24/7 coverage of national and regional news. The agency maintains strict control over its content, with all information protected by intellectual property rights. It operates under direct state oversight and funding, serving as the primary government communication channel in Djibouti.

Eri-TV is Eritrea's only television network, established in 1993 and headquartered in Asmara. Fully controlled by the Ministry of Information, it operates two channels broadcasting in Tigrinya, Arabic, English, and Tigre. As part of Eritrea's strictly controlled media landscape, ranked worst globally for press freedom, it functions as the government's primary propaganda outlet. Content distribution online is managed by Denden Media.
owner: Ministry of Information, Government of Eritrea

description: Dimtsi Hafash Eritrea (Voice of the Broad Masses of Eritrea) is Eritrea's state-controlled radio broadcasting service, established in 1979 by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front (EPLF). Originally launched during the armed struggle for independence, it has evolved from a revolutionary propaganda tool to the government's primary information outlet. The broadcaster operates under strict state control and serves as a key instrument for disseminating government messaging and national development programs.

Radio Bana is a state-controlled educational radio station based in Asmara, Eritrea, broadcasting in five languages. Operated under the Education Ministry, it has faced significant controversy with multiple journalists arrested in government crackdowns. The station broadcasts educational content and regional music, but operates under strict state control, typical of Eritrea's heavily censored media landscape. Known for broadcasting on shortwave frequencies.
owner: Ministry of Education, Government of Eritrea

description: The Eritrean Government Press is the state-controlled media apparatus of Eritrea, operating under the Ministry of Information. In a country consistently ranked as one of the world's most censored, it maintains complete control over all media outlets. Since 2001, independent media has been banned, and no foreign or national independent outlets are permitted to operate. The press serves as a propaganda tool for President Isaias Afwerki's authoritarian regime.
owner: Ministry of Information, Government of Eritrea

description: ERINA is the official state news agency of Eritrea, fully owned and governed by the Ministry of Information. Operating in a highly controlled media environment where private broadcast media and foreign ownership are banned, ERINA collects and distributes local, regional, and international news to state-owned newspapers, radio, and television outlets. The agency is entirely funded by the Eritrean government and functions as a key propaganda instrument in a country with strict media controls.

Tesfa News is a state-controlled media outlet fully funded by the Eritrean government, serving as their primary online news platform. The outlet primarily covers Eritrean news, politics, development, and sports, with a strong pro-government editorial stance. Published in both English and Tigrinya, it consistently promotes government positions and achievements while lacking critical coverage of domestic issues, functioning effectively as a government propaganda outlet based in Asmara.

Ethiopian Broadcasting Corporation (EBC), rebranded as ETV, is Ethiopia's oldest and largest state broadcaster, established in 1962 by Emperor Haile Selassie. Headquartered in Addis Ababa, it serves as the government's primary media outlet, providing news, sports, and entertainment content in multiple languages. As a fully state-owned and controlled institution, it functions as a key government communication channel, focusing on public service broadcasting while maintaining strong alignment with official state narratives and policies.

Oromia Broadcasting Network (OBN) is a leading public broadcaster headquartered in Adama, Ethiopia, serving as the state media outlet for the Oromia region. It provides news, educational content, and entertainment programming primarily in Afaan Oromoo and English languages. As the 'Voice of The People', OBN focuses on regional coverage while maintaining strong ties to the regional government, which influences its editorial direction and funding. The network plays a significant role in shaping public opinion in Ethiopia's largest regional state.

Ethiopian News Agency (ENA), established in 1942, is Ethiopia's sole national wire service and state-controlled news agency. As the country's primary news gathering and distribution organization, it provides news content to public and private media outlets. ENA produces text news, documentaries, and multimedia content in multiple languages including Amharic and English. The agency has partnerships with international news organizations like Russia's Sputnik and Italy's ANSA, and aims to become Africa's leading news agency by 2032. Under direct government control, ENA serves as the official voice of the Ethiopian government.

Walta Media and Communication Corporate S.C. (WMCC) is an Ethiopian state-owned media conglomerate based in Addis Ababa. Previously known as Walta Information Center, it operates under direct government control providing broadcast and communication services for both domestic and international audiences. The company has partnerships with state security agencies and other public broadcasters, indicating its role in state messaging and propaganda dissemination.

Kenya Broadcasting Corporation (KBC) is Kenya's state-run media organization established in 1928 (radio) and 1962 (television). Based in Nairobi, it broadcasts in English, Swahili, and various local languages. As the pioneer broadcasting house in Kenya, KBC operates both radio and TV stations, funded through government support and advertising revenue. Its mandate includes promoting economic, educational, cultural, and social welfare through public broadcasting services.

Kenya News Agency (KNA) is the flagship media outlet of Kenya's Department of Information, established in 1963 following the country's independence. Originally created as a medium for nation-building and fostering a unified Kenyan identity, it evolved from the Kenya Information Service (1939). Based in Nairobi, KNA operates as the government's primary news dissemination platform, providing news coverage through county offices nationwide. While serving as a vital information source, its state control and government oversight suggest potential influence on editorial content and narrative shaping to align with official positions.
owner: Department of Information, Ministry of Information Communication and Technology, Government of Kenya

organization: Office de la radio et de la tÃ©lÃ©vision de Malagasy (ORTM)
typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: ORTM is Madagascar's flagship public broadcaster, operating the national television station TVM and national radio station RNM. As a government-owned corporation under the Ministry of Communication, it serves as the state's primary media outlet. While providing essential public broadcasting services, its close ties to the government and state ownership structure suggest potential influence over content and editorial decisions. The organization maintains significant cultural importance, housing audiovisual heritage facilities.

Malawi Broadcasting Corporation (MBC) is the sole public broadcaster in Malawi, established in 1964 through an Act of Parliament. Operating under government control, it runs two radio stations (Radio 1 and Radio 2) and Television Malawi (TVM). The broadcaster derives its mandate from the Communications Act 1998 and is regulated by the Malawi Communications Regulatory Authority. As a state-controlled media outlet, it faces criticism for potential bias in favor of government positions and struggles with funding challenges.

TelevisÃ£o de MoÃ§ambique (TVM) is Mozambique's state-owned public television broadcaster with over 40 years of history, marking the beginning of television broadcasting in the country. As the main public television channel, it provides news, political coverage, cultural programming, and educational content. The network operates multiple channels including TVM International and TVM 2, offering comprehensive coverage of national events, government activities, and public affairs, reflecting its role as the state's primary broadcast medium.

RÃ¡dio MoÃ§ambique (RM) is Mozambique's state-owned public broadcaster established on October 2, 1975. Operating from its headquarters in Maputo, with provincial stations across all capital cities, RM broadcasts in Portuguese, English, and 19 local Bantu languages. As a state-controlled media outlet, it serves as the government's primary radio platform, providing public service broadcasting while maintaining strong ties to state interests.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: Sociedade de NotÃ­cias (SN, S.A.) is a state-owned media company in Mozambique that operates with administrative autonomy while being partially controlled by the government. Founded in 1926, it publishes the daily newspaper 'NotÃ­cias' and maintains a significant online presence. While technically a private company with state participation, its editorial line generally aligns with government positions, making it a key player in Mozambique's media landscape.

Rwanda Broadcasting Agency (RBA) is Rwanda's public service broadcaster, established in 2013 to replace ORINFOR. It operates multiple media outlets including RwandaTV, Radio Rwanda, Magic FM, KC2, and community radios, broadcasting in Kinyarwanda, French, and English. While officially described as independent from political interests, RBA is a state institution under significant government oversight, serving as the primary state media outlet in Rwanda.

Somali National Television (SNTV) is Somalia's principal public service broadcaster, established in 1983 and headquartered in Mogadishu. As the state-owned national television network, it operates under direct control of the Federal Government of Somalia with a mandate to provide public broadcasting services nationwide. While it aims to serve as a public broadcaster, its editorial independence is limited due to strong government oversight and control.

Radio Mogadishu, founded in 1951 during the Italian colonial period, is Somalia's official state-run radio station. Operating under the Ministry of Information, it has been the country's primary broadcast media outlet since independence in 1960. The station broadcasts news, educational programs, and entertainment content, playing a crucial role in disseminating government information and preserving Somalia's cultural heritage through its extensive historical archives. Located near Villa Somalia in Mogadishu, it serves as the government's main communication channel to the Somali population.
owner: Federal Government of Somalia (Ministry of Information)

description: Dalka Journal is a state-controlled media outlet operated by Somalia's Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism (MoICT). The publication focuses on reporting news, events, and developments within Somalia and related international affairs. It serves as one of the government's official communication channels, covering national politics, federal government activities, and regional developments.
owner: Federal Government of Somalia - Ministry of Information, Culture and Tourism

description: Established in 1964, SONNA is Somalia's state news agency operating under the Ministry of Information, Culture, and Tourism. As the government's primary news outlet, it covers national and international news with a focus on government activities, diplomatic relations, and development issues. While providing official state communications, it functions as a direct government mouthpiece with limited editorial independence.
owner: Federal Government of Somalia - Ministry of Information, Culture, and Tourism

description: Somaliland National Television (SLNTV) is the official public service broadcaster of the self-declared Republic of Somaliland, operating from Hargeisa. As a government-operated station, it serves as the primary state media outlet broadcasting news, entertainment, religious content, and sports programming. The channel has international reach across Europe, Africa, Asia and America, though it primarily serves the Somaliland region's information needs under direct state control.

Radio Hargeysa, established in 1943, is the largest Somali-language broadcaster and the official state radio of Somaliland. Operating under the Ministry of Information in Hargeisa, it broadcasts nationwide through FM and shortwave frequencies (7120 kHz). The station has played a significant historical role in the region, surviving through Somalia's civil conflicts. As a government-owned broadcaster, it serves as Somaliland's primary public service media outlet, primarily focusing on news, cultural programs, and government communications.

SOLNA is the state news agency of the self-declared Republic of Somaliland, operating under direct government control. It monitors and reports local, regional, and international news in multiple languages including Somali, Arabic, English, and Amharic. The agency functions as the government's primary media outlet, consistently promoting official state positions and narratives, particularly regarding territorial disputes and political matters.

Dawan Media Group (DMG), established in 1998 as Mandeeq Media Group, is Somalia's state-controlled media conglomerate. It operates multiple publications in different languages: Dawan (Somali), The Horn Tribune (English), and Alqaran (Arabic). Originally established by presidential decree, it works closely with the Somaliland News Agency (SOLNA) to disseminate government-approved news and information to the public through various media outlets.

South Sudan Broadcasting Corporation (SSBC) is the state-owned national broadcaster of South Sudan, operating from the capital Juba. It provides television and radio services in English and Juba Arabic through various platforms including satellite (Arabsat Badr-4, DSTV), online streaming, and terrestrial transmission. While established under the Broadcasting Corporation Act of 2013 to promote high-quality broadcasting and guarantee independence, SSBC functions as a government mouthpiece with strong state control over its editorial content and programming, primarily focusing on news, current affairs, and entertainment.
owner: Government of South Sudan (Ministry of Information, Communication Technology and Postal Services)

description: Sudan TV, operated by SNBC since 1962, is Sudan's primary state-owned Arabic language television network broadcasting from Khartoum. As the main terrestrial channel in a media landscape dominated by state control, it serves as the government's primary broadcast outlet. Out of Sudan's 18 terrestrial channels, only one is not state-owned, highlighting the government's tight grip on media. The network primarily functions as a government mouthpiece, with programming heavily influenced by state interests and policies.

Sudan Radio is the state-controlled national broadcaster of Sudan, operating under direct government oversight. The station broadcasts primarily in Arabic and English, providing news, cultural programs, and government messaging. As a state media outlet, it serves as a primary propaganda tool for the ruling regime, with content strictly aligned with government positions and policies. The station has historically been used to promote official narratives during periods of conflict and political transition.

Sudan News Agency (SUNA), established in 1970, is Sudan's official state news agency providing news in Arabic, English, and French. As one of Africa's leading news agencies, SUNA serves as the government's primary information distribution channel. While it claims to be an independent public media organization, it operates under direct state control and functions as the official press agency of the Republic of Sudan, primarily disseminating government-approved information and perspectives.

Tanzania Broadcasting Corporation (TBC) is Tanzania's national public broadcaster, established under the Public Corporation Act of 1992. As the only public broadcaster on Tanzania mainland, it provides radio and television services from Dar es Salaam. While its mandate is to educate, inform, and entertain through quality programming accessible to all citizens regardless of ideology, race, religion, gender, class, or disability, it is fully government-owned and controlled, operating as a state media entity.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: Tanzania Standard Newspapers (TSN) is a state-owned media corporation established in 1970 under the Public Corporation Act. It publishes Tanzania's leading newspapers including Daily News, Sunday News, HabariLEO, and SpotiLEO. As a government-owned entity, it operates under direct state control and serves as the primary print media outlet in Tanzania, publishing both English and Swahili language content. The company maintains significant influence in Tanzania's media landscape as a state mouthpiece.
owner: Government of the United Republic of Tanzania

description: Zanzibar Broadcasting Corporation (ZBC) is Tanzania's state-owned broadcaster for the semi-autonomous region of Zanzibar, established in 2013 through legislation signed by Zanzibar's President. It operates multiple platforms including television and radio stations (ZBC Radio and Spice FM). As a government institution indicated by its .go.tz domain, it serves as the official state media outlet for Zanzibar, primarily broadcasting in Swahili and focusing on local news and cultural content.

Zanzibar Newspaper Corporation (ZNC) is a state-controlled media company in Zanzibar, Tanzania, established by law in 2008. It publishes several newspapers including 'Zanzibar Leo', 'Zanzibar Leo Jumapili', 'Zaspoti', and 'Zanzibar Mail'. The organization's managing editor is directly appointed by the President of Zanzibar, indicating strong government control. ZNC is one of the principal state-run publishers in Sub-Saharan Africa.

Uganda Broadcasting Corporation (UBC) is Uganda's national public broadcaster, established in 2005 through the merger of Uganda Television and Radio Uganda. Wholly owned by the government and operating under the Ministry of Information and Communications Technology, UBC operates eleven radio stations and four television channels. Its mandate includes providing educational, informative, and entertainment content for national development. The network aims to be a broadcasting center of excellence, though it faces competition from other media outlets.
owner: Government of Uganda through Uganda Ministry of Information and Communications Technology

organization: The New Vision Printing & Publishing Company (Vision Group)
typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: Vision Group is Uganda's leading multimedia conglomerate, publishing the English-language daily New Vision newspaper and operating various media outlets. Founded in 1986 from the defunct Uganda Times, it is majority-owned by the Ugandan government with some institutional and private investors. As a state-owned enterprise, it maintains close ties to the government while operating as a publicly traded company on the Uganda Securities Exchange.
owner: Government of Uganda (majority stake), Institutional and Individual Investors (minority stake)

description: The Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation (ZNBC) is Zambia's primary state broadcaster operating as a statutory body under the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting Services (MIBS). It provides radio and television broadcasting services within Zambia and beyond its borders through modern broadcasting equipment. While technically a statutory body, ZNBC maintains strong government ties and serves as a strategic state institution, potentially affecting its editorial independence. The broadcaster offers comprehensive event coverage and operates multiple media platforms, making it the country's largest broadcasting service provider.
owner: Ministry of Information and Broadcasting Services (MIBS), Government of Zambia

description: The Industrial Development Corporation (IDC) is Zambia's state-owned investment holding company established in 2014 to oversee and manage state-owned enterprises. Operating under the Office of the President, it manages government investments in various sectors including mining, energy, agriculture, and telecommunications. While officially mandated to drive industrialization and economic growth, IDC faces challenges of political interference and transparency issues in its operations. The corporation manages over 30 state-owned enterprises, acting as the government's primary investment arm.

ZANIS is Zambia's state-controlled media organization formed in 2005 through the merger of ZANA and ZIS. As the government's primary public relations and news outlet, it operates under the Ministry of Information and Media, providing nationwide coverage through journalists stationed across the country. ZANIS interprets government policies and delivers state-approved information through various platforms including TV (launched 2024), focusing on promoting government programs and development initiatives.
owner: Government of Zambia - Ministry of Information and Media

description: The Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation (ZBC) is Zimbabwe's state-owned national broadcaster, operating six radio stations and the main television network ZBC TV (ZTV). Established in 1980 from the former Rhodesian Broadcasting Corporation, it serves as the primary source of news about Zimbabwe. The broadcaster is widely recognized as a government propaganda outlet with strict state control over content and editorial decisions, consistently favoring the ruling party's narrative and limiting opposition voices.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: Zimbabwe Newspapers (1980) Limited, operating as Zimpapers, is Zimbabwe's oldest and largest state-controlled media conglomerate. Listed on the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange, it operates across print, broadcasting, and digital media. While presenting itself as a commercial entity, it functions as a government propaganda outlet, consistently promoting ZANU-PF party interests and state narratives. The company owns major newspapers like The Herald, runs Star FM radio station, and Zimpapers TV Network, effectively controlling much of Zimbabwe's mainstream media landscape through state oversight via the Zimbabwe Mass Media Trust.

New Ziana is Zimbabwe's official state news agency with nationwide coverage and international correspondent relationships. As the country's sole official news agency, it operates under direct state control and serves as a primary government communications channel. The agency covers national news, with particular focus on government initiatives, economic development, and state policies, reflecting the official government perspective in its reporting.

The Department of Broadcasting Services is Botswana's state broadcaster operating Radio Botswana (RB), Radio Botswana 2, and Botswana Television (BTV). Established in 2000, it is directly controlled by the government with the president's office determining editorial policy. As the dominant broadcast media outlet in Botswana, it maintains tight control over content distribution, particularly in radio which is a crucial medium in the country. The broadcaster primarily serves as a government communication channel.

The Department of Information Technology is a government agency under Botswana's Ministry of Communications, Knowledge and Technology. It provides essential digital services including government website hosting, internet connectivity, and information systems governance. The department plays a crucial role in coordinating the dissemination of information about Botswana's political, social, and economic developments, operating under direct state control to support national development goals.

Lesotho National Broadcasting Services (LNBS) is the state-owned media hub operating under the Ministry of Communications of Lesotho. Established in 1966 after independence, it operates Radio Lesotho (founded 1964), Ultimate Radio (English service, launched 2006), and Lesotho Television (LTV) - the country's only TV channel. LNBS provides news and public broadcasting services while being fully controlled and funded by the government, serving as the primary state media outlet in Lesotho.

Lesotho News Agency (LENA) is the state-owned news agency of Lesotho, established in 1985. As a government institution operating under a .gov.ls domain, it serves as the primary news outlet covering both urban and rural areas throughout the country. The agency focuses on national politics, international relations, and local developments, providing official government communications and news coverage.

The Namibian Broadcasting Corporation (NBC) is Namibia's state-owned public broadcaster, established in 1979 as the South West African Broadcasting Corporation. Supervised by a board appointed by the Minister of Information and Communication Technology, NBC operates TV, radio (including 11 stations), and digital platforms. Its mandate includes providing nationwide broadcasting services that inform, educate, and entertain while promoting nation-building and English language usage. The broadcaster is fully state-funded and controlled through the Namibian Broadcasting Act of 1991.
owner: Government of Namibia (Ministry of Information and Communication Technology)

description: New Era Publications Corporation (NEPC) is Namibia's leading government news organization, wholly owned by the Government of the Republic of Namibia. While operating as an autonomous entity with a board-directed structure, it has faced recent controversies over press freedom and censorship concerns. The organization has experienced significant financial challenges, with substantial losses in recent years. The publisher produces the New Era newspaper and other publications, focusing on political, socio-economic, and cultural news.
owner: Government of the Republic of Namibia (100%)

description: The Namibia Press Agency (NAMPA) is Namibia's sole national news agency, established in 1991 (formerly Namibia Press Association in 1987). As a state-owned entity, it operates across print, broadcast, and digital media platforms, distributing local, regional, and international news throughout Southern Africa and beyond. Despite being state-controlled, Namibia enjoys relatively high media freedom compared to neighboring countries. NAMPA serves as the primary news source for most Namibian media outlets, particularly for international coverage, with operations spanning multiple regional offices including Windhoek, Swakopmund, and Ongwediva/Oshakati.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: Established in 1936, the South African Broadcasting Corporation (SABC) is South Africa's state-owned public broadcaster and one of the country's largest state enterprises. It operates multiple TV channels, 19 radio stations, and SABC+, its streaming platform launched in 2022. While mandated to provide accessible content in all official languages and reflect South Africa's cultural diversity, it faces criticism for government influence. The broadcaster aims to inform, educate, and entertain while ensuring nationwide coverage, though its editorial independence has been questioned.

The Government Communication and Information System (GCIS), established in 1998, is South Africa's official government communications department that provides strategic communication leadership and coordination across all government entities. Operating under the Minister in the Presidency, GCIS manages government messaging, media relations, and public information dissemination. It produces official publications, coordinates communication strategy, and ensures government services information reaches citizens. The organization has faced scrutiny in state capture investigations, highlighting its significant role in government messaging control.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: Independent Media is one of South Africa's largest multi-platform media companies, operating numerous prominent newspapers and digital platforms. Despite its name suggesting independence, it is controlled by Sekunjalo Investments under Dr. Iqbal SurvÃ©'s leadership. The company has faced controversy over its editorial practices, including withdrawing from the South African Press Council. It owns 20 major print and digital news outlets, including The Star newspaper and IOL news website, making it one of the four dominant media groups in South Africa.

organization: SociÃ©tÃ© de radio et de tÃ©lÃ©vision du BÃ©nin (SRTB)
description: SRTB is Benin's public broadcaster, formed in 2023 through the merger of ORTB (Office de radiodiffusion et tÃ©lÃ©vision du BÃ©nin) and CMAJB (Centre multimÃ©dia des Adolescents et des Jeunes du BÃ©nin). The organization's history dates back to 1972 when it was established as ORTD. It operates multiple radio stations including Radio BÃ©nin, Radio Parakou, and Radio BÃ©nin Alafia, serving as the state's primary public media service.

organization: Office national d'imprimerie et de presse
description: The Office national d'imprimerie et de presse (ONIP) is Benin's state-owned media and printing company, operating under government supervision. It publishes 'La Nation', the country's leading state newspaper founded in 1969 as Daho-Express. As a state institution with social, cultural, and scientific missions, ONIP serves as the government's primary media outlet, operating under direct state control and funding.

Radiodiffusion TÃ©lÃ©vision du Burkina (RTB) is the state-owned public broadcaster of Burkina Faso, operating both television and radio services. As the most-watched channel in the country according to INSD statistics, RTB serves as the primary media outlet for government communications and national news. The broadcaster extensively covers state activities, military operations, and government initiatives, reflecting its role as a state media apparatus under the current transitional military government led by Captain Ibrahim Traore.

typology: Independent State Funded and State Managed/Owned Media
description: Sidwaya is a French-language national daily newspaper in Burkina Faso, founded in 1984 during Thomas Sankara's regime after closing the independent Observateur. Originally a state newspaper, it has evolved to become a reference publication for the BurkinabÃ© population. While maintaining government ties, it provides general news coverage primarily in Ouagadougou and regional capitals. The newspaper has gained recognition for its journalism, with notable achievements including its journalist Mariam OuÃ©draogo becoming the first African winner of the Bayeux War Correspondents Prize.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: RTC is Cape Verde's largest state-owned media company, operating both radio and television services. As the primary broadcaster in Cape Verde, it provides comprehensive coverage of national news, politics, and cultural content, including interviews with government officials and coverage of significant events like elections and sports. The network maintains a strong presence across the archipelago with offices in multiple islands including Praia, SÃ£o Vicente, Sal, and Fogo. While government-owned, it serves as the main source of public broadcasting for Cape Verde's population.

Inforpress is Cape Verde's sole national news agency with over 30 years of experience, serving as a vital link between Cape Verde, its diaspora, and the world. As the official state news agency, it focuses on producing factual news content with a commitment to objectivity and credibility. The agency maintains nationwide coverage and is responsible for collecting, processing, and distributing news content. While government-owned, it strives to maintain editorial standards focused on factual, impartial, and reliable information.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: Radiodiffusion-TÃ©lÃ©vision ivoirienne (RTI) is CÃ´te d'Ivoire's state-owned broadcasting company, operating multiple TV channels (RTI1, RTI2, RTI3) and radio stations (FrÃ©quence 2, Radio CÃ´te d'Ivoire). As the country's main public broadcaster, it provides news, entertainment, and cultural programming. While positioned as a public service media group, it maintains strong ties to the government and generally aligns with official state positions. Recently upgraded with modern equipment for major event coverage like CAN 2023, RTI reaches audiences across Africa through satellite distribution.

organization: SociÃ©tÃ© Nouvelle de Presse et d'Edition de CÃ´te d'Ivoire (SNPECI)
typology: Independent State Funded and State Managed/Owned Media
description: SNPECI is a state-owned publishing house in CÃ´te d'Ivoire established following the dissolution of SII and SPECI. Its main publication is FraternitÃ© Matin, a widely read government tabloid newspaper founded in 1964. The company is overseen by a state-appointed board of directors and serves as the primary government media outlet in CÃ´te d'Ivoire, focusing on news publishing and editorial services.

typology: Independent State Funded and State Managed/Owned Media
description: The Agence Ivoirienne de Presse (AIP) is Ivory Coast's state news agency, established in 1961. Based in Abidjan, it positions itself as the leader in local news coverage in CÃ´te d'Ivoire. While state-funded and managed, AIP maintains editorial independence, focusing on delivering accurate, diverse, and impartial news coverage. The agency has gained recognition for its journalistic excellence, recently winning multiple awards from the Atlantic Federation of African Press Agencies (FAAPA).

The Ghana Broadcasting Corporation (GBC), established in 1935 and formalized by law in 1968, is Ghana's state-owned national broadcaster with a triple mandate as State, Public Service, and Commercial Broadcaster. Operating 7 TV stations including the flagship GTV channel, GBC provides comprehensive news coverage and public service content. Led by Director-General Prof. Amin Alhassan, it serves as the government's primary media outlet while striving to maintain editorial standards. The broadcaster plays a crucial role in national events, including election coverage and public awareness campaigns.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: Established in 1950 by the Daily Mirror Group of Britain as the West African Graphic Company Limited, GCGL is now Ghana's leading state-owned media company. Originally a private business, it was later nationalized and is currently owned by the Ghanaian government. The company operates with a mission to provide accurate information while maintaining strong ties with government interests. Recently, the government has affirmed its commitment to maintaining state ownership while pursuing recapitalization.

typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: New Times Corporation (NTC) is a state-owned media organization established in 1957 by Ghana's first President Kwame Nkrumah, originally as The Guinea Press Limited. It publishes the Ghanaian Times and The Spectator newspapers and is regulated by the National Media Commission. The organization is governed by a nine-member board appointed by the state, reflecting strong government oversight of its operations.

The Ghana News Agency (GNA), established in 1957 by Kwame Nkrumah, is Ghana's first and primary state-owned news agency, and was the first news agency in Sub-Saharan Africa. While it claims to provide accurate, credible, and objective news coverage, it operates under state control and oversight. The agency's core mandate is collecting, processing, and disseminating news both domestically and internationally. GNA covers a wide range of topics including politics, social issues, sports, and cultural events, serving as Ghana's preferred news source. While it maintains professional standards, its state ownership and control may influence its editorial perspective and coverage of government-related matters.

The Liberia Broadcasting System (LBS) is a state-owned radio and television network, serving as the official voice of Liberia. Founded in 1960 by Rediffusion London, it transferred to government control in 1968. LBS operates multiple channels including ELBC Radio (99.9), LNTV, Metro FM (89.9), and recently launched Indigenous Radio (97.7). As the state broadcaster, it explicitly propagates government policy and is undergoing modernization with Chinese support. The network has expanded with new state-of-the-art facilities but maintains strong government editorial control.

The Liberia News Agency (LINA), established in 1979, is Liberia's state-owned central news collection agency operating under the Ministry of Information, Culture Affairs, and Tourism (MICAT). As the only media institution with national coverage in Liberia, it focuses on promoting government's development agenda and national integration. While there have been attempts to make it autonomous, LINA remains under direct state control and primarily serves as a government communication channel.
owner: Government of Liberia (Ministry of Information, Culture Affairs, and Tourism)

organization: Office de la Radiodiffusion Television du Mali (ORTM)
description: ORTM is Mali's state broadcaster, operating as a public administrative institution with management autonomy. Based in Bamako, it broadcasts primarily in French (80%) with the remaining content in local languages. The network has partnerships with Canal France International for programming content. As the national broadcaster, it serves as the government's primary media outlet, reflecting state interests and policies.

organization: Agence Malienne de Presse et de PublicitÃ© (AMAP)
typology: Captured Public or State Managed/Owned Media
description: AMAP is Mali's state-owned news agency and advertising company, serving as the country's primary official press organization. It operates under direct government oversight, providing daily news coverage with a focus on national affairs, government communications, and public announcements.
